commentBody: Delightful! I loved that UP or DOWN could go in either way. Very clever!
This was breezy and fun to solve, maybe a tad too easy for a Wednesday

Found this article on Crosswords in a PBS Masterpiece newsletter. I posted it late in the Wednesday Wordplay column, so I'm reposting on the Thursday Wordplay column. https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/masterpiece/specialfeatures/crossword-puzzle-trivia-surprising-facts-and-history/ Enjoy!

Usually, it‚Äôs the quarterback who takes a KNEE, but today we found out that it was the tight end that did it, and Swiftly ushered in a new ERA. 

How prescient to have planned both words for tonight‚Äôs puzzle!
Totally lived up to the hype created by yesterday's constructor's notes. Easy but nice aha moment when I got the theme. Sign me up for a Schroedinger any day.

This one had its UPs and DOWNs.  I thought it was a simple rebus, and entered UP in all the circled squares.  I was charmed to find that DOWN worked as well and that the rebuses worked both ways.  That was a very neat trick in my book.

I was so chuffed to get in the first comment that I forgot to say: I think Ms. Zhang should reconsider wanting quantity over quality of comments. Seems like the puzzles with the most comments around here are the ones where there's a "trick" that gets everyone riled up or a deviation from the expected "hardness level". I think if I was a constructor I'd be happy with fewer comments, which would mean everyone found it perfectly cromulent and not worth complaining about (Lol).

A shiver runs UP/DOWN your spine when you realize you get to Schr√∂dingize! (my favorite puzzle flavor).

Zhou, our Wednesday fun was UP to you, and now it is DOWN to you!
Up, Up, Down, Down, Left, Right, Left, Right, B, A, Start
I may be missing something, but why is 54A missing the p in UP

Great back to back themes. Great love story. But the thing that really hit home was the amount of rejection it takes finally to succeed in the constructing world at the NYT level. Stories of perseverance always welcome!
Since I posted a comment for Kevin, it seems only right I post a comment for Zhou, too. I don't want to get in the middle of THAT little competition.

The biggest DOWNside to a puzzle like this is that when it doesn't ding I don't know if it's because I screwed UP or because I couldn't figure out how the rebus wanted to be entered (which I argue is not me screwing up). Turned out I had a typo so YAYME for getting it eventually. I hope this puzzle makes anti-rebus people more open to them because it seems like a relatively low friction introduction. But if you just don't want a rebus in your crossword I get it. I don't like puzzles in my RPGs.
Clever puzzle!
I‚Äôm up/down to help her get more comments ‚Äî I mean, I commented yesterday and if I don‚Äôt write something down/up, I‚Äôll feel guilty.
Brilliant!

It didn't take me long to see that either up or down would fly in the circled squares in this delightful Wednesday rebus puzzle. For those that fear the rebus, this should provide a gentle entry path to successfully solving one.
One more for Team Zhou!

What goes up, must come down. - Newton

If you push something hard enough, it will fall over. - Fudd

Half of what goes in here must come out there. - Teslacle

Zhou Zhang, I'll add a comment to your count. Loved it. A perfect Wednesday. I think this may have been my first Schr√∂dinger since I've only been solving since December, unless I'm forgetting one. Like Sam, I entered all the UPs first and only figured out the alternate DOWNs when I got to 51D. Did anyone else have PRIcE for 32D and as a result, get stuck on 46A for a bit? Took a second to realize "Value" was a verb in this case. And now for something truly silly... references to BLACKPINK make me think of poor JENNIE's reaction to spicy wings in this episode of Hot Ones: https://youtu.be/sUl6zhUKeAw?si=ID1HhX8vm3AW9ogq

Congratulations, Zhou!  This was a fun and clever puzzle. I particularly enjoyed discovering the ups and downs could both work as answers. Kevin promised an impressive puzzle for today and he wasn‚Äôt wrong. Thank you both for the back-to-back joy of solving!
Kevin did not oversell it -- this was amazing! A true Schrodinger, beautifully built and clued. These two puzzles back to back are something really to be proud of. Thanks so much!
My favorite dessert is upside down cake - this was sweet and chewy - perfect to solve our Wednesday evening munchies.

When I realized a rebus was needed, and that UP and DOWN would solve either direction, I entered "UP/DOWN" as my rebus entry all 4 times. I was a bit concerned that maybe I should be alternating with "DOWN/UP", but once I fixed an unrelated typo, I got the congratulatory gold star, so it seems there's at least 16 "correct" answers to this puzzle (4 squares that can be filled in with any of the 4 above answers). 

If just the first letters U and D are also accepted (which is often the case with a rebus entry) then add another 16 ways to solve it. 

Maybe 32 correct solutions is too many correct solutions?
I want more Zhou Zhang puzzles!  Love her name and loved this crossword!  Fun rebus for a Wednesday - more please!
The letter ‚ÄúZ‚Äù priZe.  Nicely done.  Make me put in the whole alphabet to figure out why PRICE isn‚Äôt VALUE‚Ä¶precise definitions notwithstanding l.

Am I allowed to ask how in the world to get the website version of the crossword to accept the two words in the rebus as the correct answer? I know how to put words in one square but not how to stack them as the answer key shows. It makes me sad / mad that I might lose my answer streak because the technology is defeating me.

Great puzzle! I confidently filled in DOWN for all the rebuses, and didn‚Äôt realize they all could have been UP until I started reading this column! I‚Äôd be curious to know the percentage of solvers who went with UP vs. DOWN vs. some combination of the two?

I love schroedinger puzzles!  I spent a few minutes trying to figure out where the extra four circles were (4 ups and 4 downs) ... then I noticed the "could" and also changed my mind on which way to go on BUTTON_ ... which in turn led me to realize the duality. 

Very nice :)

But I am rooting for you on the comment count.  
It would be epic if you could hit a stretch goal of 1000.
But you know only hated puzzles can get to that high a count.

Go Zhou!

What would you do?  I made the decision any normal puzzle addict should.

My PhD advisor often would answer ‚ÄúYes, no‚Ä¶.‚Äù or ‚ÄúNo, yes.‚Äù  It was the 1980s and me and the other students wrote a command on our big shared mainframe computer to type in the latest example and whether after more sentences he really meant yes or no.  

About 80% of the time it was the second word that had the correct meaning.

And speaking of quantum and Schr√∂dinger‚Ä¶ a close colleague in physics of my advisor (B Peters ) was falsely accused by J. Robert Oppenheimer of being Communist.
Great puzzle, well done!
I enjoyed both of your puzzles :)
value is a lousy clue for "prize".  Even if you consider value as a verb, when you value something, you don't prize something.  And as a noun, a value is not a prize.  Lousy clue.

There was some concern yesterday that Kevin‚Äôs kind words on his wife‚Äôs puzzle would lead to unwarranted positive comments for her. I hope there‚Äôs no doubting it, this puzzle certainly deserves praise on its own merits. Both puzzles were extremely original and had smooth solves. The downs were a little bit of cheating since they presented both sides of opposites but the acrosses literally meant the same thing with either preposition which is a devilish feat (and it was consistent between the downs and ups).

I have to say, though, it seems unfair to take advantage of your husband‚Äôs good nature to win this friendly competition! If it gets down to the wire I may have to go to yesterday‚Äôs puzzle and add another comment or two, just on principle‚Ä¶

Well, this puzzle certainly had its Ups and Downs! (Oh, come on. Someone had to do it.)

The Up: I love me a good Schr√∂dinger, and this one did not disappoint. I found it clever, breezy, and fun.

The Down: The intersection of 46A and 32D. I was sure 32D was ‚Äúprice‚Äù, but ‚ÄúHACE‚Äù didn‚Äôt make sense‚Äî until I looked it up and learned it‚Äôs an acronym for a type of altitude sickness that causes, among other things, confusion! 

So I left that alone and looked for my error elsewhere. Never did find it, of course, so I ended up with a Check Puzzle cheat and a blue star. 

But despite that, I land firmly on the Up side. I‚Äôm an optimist, and I like the color blue. This was a lovely debut. Please come back and play again soon, Zhou!

How can Zhou beat Kevin's comment total? 

Rebuses, of course!

I‚Äôve been lurking silently in the comments for several weeks without posting, but since Zhou asked nicely (albeit competitively), I‚Äôm adding to her count. Which is not to say I‚Äôm not on Kevin‚Äôs team, too. I loved both puzzles and both constructor‚Äôs notes. And Sam, you had me at ‚ÄúSchronanigans‚Äù!

One last comment tonight so I don‚Äôt tilt the scales. It‚Äôs an interesting quirk in English that UP can be used to mean ‚Äúcompletely‚Äù. I can clean my room a little bit, but if I ‚Äúclean it up‚Äù it‚Äôs all clean. I can eat some cake but if I ‚Äúeat up‚Äù the cake‚Äù it‚Äôs all gone. There‚Äôs a lot of examples of this.

DIANA is a wild reach for Roman goddess of fertility. Shocked nobody else has mentioned it. Goddess of childbirth, yes. But that is not the same as the fertility, and the Romans certainly didn't believe so.

A clue of ‚ÄúMan where?‚Äù could be MANUP or MANDOWN.  Helping the comment count!

This was a lovely puzzle, and I say all that without really noticing the Schr√∂dinger element until I came to the Wordplay comment. In fact, I find the ‚ÄúSchr√∂dinger‚Äù trick to be the only disappointing piece, because it‚Äôs really just exploiting the fact that English uses ‚Äúup‚Äù and ‚Äúdown‚Äù interchangeably in many idioms, with either no change to their meaning or a perfectly symmetric meaning. That‚Äôs all fair game, but for my money, the joy of these quantum-superposition puzzles is when the same clue can lead to multiple different answers with different meanings. It would have been great to see some answers where ‚ÄúUP‚Äù and ‚ÄúDOWN‚Äù function as something other than a direction, though admittedly that‚Äôs a tough constraint to make work in a rebus. As is, the crosses feel a bit like rhyming a word with itself.

Anyway! I don‚Äôt mean to sound grumpy, because I really found yesterday and today to be among the best Tuesday and Wednesday puzzles in recent memory. Just trying to put my finger on why the ‚Äúaha!‚Äù moment didn‚Äôt work its magic on me.

At that point I went from ‚Äúthis is a fun little trick‚Äù to ‚Äúthis is genius‚Äù.

It tapped into a linguistic quirk I‚Äôve always found interesting (is there any difference between up for something or down for something?) and I like that all the down clues cover polar opposites while the across clues cover similar/identical meanings.

Then some fun phrases (‚Äúyay me‚Äù, ‚Äúoh be a pal‚Äù) and fun clues (‚Äúcontents of some boats‚Äù, ‚Äúhides a tear, say‚Äù) helped the puzzle hit my sweet spot. Great stuff.

many of these pairs are synonyms or opposites.

but one of them is not a pair of synonyms (even though people think it is sometimes), nor opposites...

button-up refers to a shirt with a placket of buttons in front. but a button-down refers to a shirt (usually a button-up) in which the collar tabs have additional buttons that can hold them down to the front of the shirt.

And on that topic, I will comment that Sam‚Äôs Wordplay column was my introduction to the term Schr√∂dinger puzzle. (Evidently, I am late to the party on that one. Or maybe I arrived at the party and found no-one else there? Kind of reminds me of the Mad Hatter‚Äôs tea party scene. More on Alice a bit later.). As an aside, I must give Sam full marks for what struck me ‚Äî- no bias here ‚Äî as a brilliant bit of writing to introduce me to the concept of a Schr√∂dinger puzzle. It got me to thinking about Lewis Carroll‚Äôs Cheshire Cat whose smile persisted after the cat disappeared. And then a brilliant thought ‚Äî to me, anyway‚Äî occurred. What do Lewis Carroll and Schr√∂dinger have in common? So naturally I googled the two names and, wonder of wonders, up (down?) popped this article from the Washington Post: https://www.wsj.com/articles/lewis-carroll-a-pioneer-of-quantum-physics-1446670384 You might enjoy it. Between today‚Äôs puzzle and yesterday‚Äôs, this one wins.

Yesterday‚Äôs main gimmick was asymmetry, always used in service of a theme. There have been 44 asymmetric puzzles, rare enough.

Today‚Äôs is a Schr√∂dinger puzzle, which are even rarer.  There have been just 21 of those. It‚Äôs also a rebus puzzle. There have been just 3 rebus Schr√∂dinger puzzles ever.  And of those three puzzles, only this one has letters that behave like a normal rebus.  (The others had three letters in two spaces, with the middle letter jumping from one square to the other for the alternative, or an alternation of one or two letters in the Schr√∂dinger square.)

So while the other puzzle was clever and rare, this one is a unicorn.

- Button-Down Shirt: This refers specifically to a shirt with buttons on the collar points that fasten to the shirt. It‚Äôs a detail originally designed to keep collars from flapping during polo matches ‚Äî hence its sporty, Ivy League vibe.
- Button-Up Shirt: This is the broader term for any shirt that buttons up the front, regardless of the collar style. So all button-downs are button-ups, but not all button-ups are button-downs.

@Michael Hendler
What CatLadyMargaret said. If looking in your "In Progress" section*, you find, say, an unfinished puzzle from 2022 and finish it today, it doesn't count towards any streak, but you do get credit for completing the puzzle. So if you work at catching up, you can eventually build your completion solve rate to 100%. 

You may need to look up some answers in Wikipedia or websearch to find some old Wordplay columns and answer sheets (remember Wordplay columns are dated one day earlier than the puzzle) to get past clues that still stump you. Different people have different standards for "completing" a puzzle. Some only want credit for puzzles they solved with no help. Others want credit for puzzles they solved with help. Whatever works for you is fine by me.

If I recall correctly, to locate your incomplete puzzles under "In Progress," at least on a web browser on a PC, open the NYT Games page. In the upper left, open a menu by clicking on the 3 horizontal bars. Next to "The Crossword" click the arrow to open a new menu and choose "Statistics." I believe "In Progress" puzzles appear on that page. Since I finished all mine and am now at 100% complete (my streaks are pretty short, though!), I don't see "In Progress" anymore, for me, so I'm not sure that's right, but that's what I remember.

@Michael Hendler
Oh yeah, I just remembered, you can also use Autocheck, if you're stuck on an old puzzle. Using Autocheck ends a streak, but an Autochecked puzzle still counts as completed for calculating your completion solve rate. Since an old puzzle can't count towards a streak, anyway, there's no downside to using Autocheck on old puzzles, as long as you're comfortable getting credit even though you got some help.
